message: Wishing you and your family a happy new year!  In case you missed it: my office hours for the month of January are up on my website.   See when a staffer will be nearest you: http://roe.house.gov/constituentservices/officehours/.

Serving the First Congressional District is a privilege, and I am honored and excited to be given this opportunity. For the last eight years, Tennesseans have struggled under President Obama’s reckless and misguided policies, and I look forward to working with President-elect Trump in the new Congress to get our country back on track. Whether it’s creating and keeping good-paying jobs in the United States, repealing Obamacare, standing up for life, defending our Constitutionally-granted rights or finally reforming the VA to get veterans the care and services they’ve earned – I know I’ve got my work cut out for me.   Tennesseans deserve results, and I’m ready to roll up my sleeves and help change the direction of this country. I thank East Tennesseans for this tremendous honor and the trust they’ve placed in me, and I encourage anyone in the First District who needs assistance with a federal agency to contact any of my offices.

I look forward to working with my colleagues in the House and Senate, as well as President-elect Trump and the Trump administration, to fundamentally change the way the VA does business.   And we aren't wasting any time getting started.
I hope you'll take a moment to read my weekly column on my website:

Yesterday I reintroduced my plan to repeal and replace #Obamacare. My bill is only 184 pages, and will get the federal government out of health care. Americans have been struggling under President Obama’s failed policies for far too long, and they deserve real affordable healthcare options.   This legislation has received widespread support in the Conference across multiple Congresses, and proposes a strong conservative vision for the American health care system. The American Health Care Reform Act will do the things President Obama promised and failed to do through his health law: increase access to and lower the cost of health care. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the House and Senate, and with President-elect Trump and the Trump administration, to repeal and replace Obamacare with patient-centered, free market health care reform.  You can read the bill here: http://rsc-walker.house.gov/files/Initiatives/AHCRA%20-%20Final%20Bill%20Text%20115th.pdf

President Obama and Democrats in Congress say Republicans have no ideas for health care reform. That's just not true. Republicans have put forward plenty of ideas for reform, and I hope my bill can help pave the way to repeal Obamacare and replace it with a law that will actually work for patients and health care providers.
I was glad to have the opportunity to be the keynote speaker at the Hermitage's annual Battle of New Orleans ceremony in Nashville on Sunday.

IN CASE YOU MISSED IT: Yesterday, I spoke on the House floor in support of H.R. 315, the Improving Access to Maternity Care Act. This legislation would require the Health Resources and Services Administration to designate maternity health care professional shortage areas and target maternity care resources where they’re most needed, helping to ensure healthier pregnancies and healthier babies.

Proud to support this effort to honor Senator Fred Thompson.  Senator Thompson rose from humble beginnings to national prominence through hard work and perseverance. Fred dedicated much of his life to serving the state of Tennessee and this great country, and I am proud to join the Tennessee delegation to honor the memory of a great man I was lucky to call a friend.

I am pleased President-elect Trump has chosen a physician to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs, especially one familiar with the integrating of private practitioners into the VA's network of health care providers. I’ve long said I would be happy to work with anyone committed to ensuring our heroes have access to the services they have earned, especially quality health care, and I look forward to working with Dr. Shulkin to bring wholesale reform to the Department.

I made a promise to fight to repeal Obamacare, and I am going to keep that promise. Read what Republicans in Congress are doing this week to set the stage for President-elect Trump to quickly repeal Obamacare in my weekly column:

In 2011, when the American people put Republicans in charge of the House of Representatives, we made a promise that we would repeal the fundamentally flawed Affordable Care Act and replace it with patient-centered, market-driven health care reforms. I am proud to support the budget today, which is the first step on the path towards fulfilling that promise.   For the last seven years, I’ve been contacted by numerous East Tennesseans who are concerned about the impacts of President Obama’s health care law. Since this law went into effect, they’ve seen their premiums increase and their options for health coverage dwindle. Make no mistake: this law has failed, and it’s past time we provide much-needed relief and more affordable coverage options to the hardworking Americans suffering because of it.
Tennesseans are struggling under #Obamacare, but relief is on the way.

Republicans are here to transform the health care system & make it more affordable & patient-centric. I practiced medicine for 31 years. Doctors and patients, NOT insurance companies and the government, should make health care decisions. Today I went on Fox Business to talk about the Republican vision for the American health care system.

Tomorrow, our country will take part in one of our most sacred and special traditions: the peaceful transition of power from one President of the United States to the next. Inauguration Day is a celebration that dates back to the very beginning of our country, but the first president to take the oath of office in Washington, D.C. was Thomas Jefferson in 1801.   As a Congressman, I consider it an honor and duty to participate in the inauguration of a new president, no matter what party the president-elect hails from. I look forward to witnessing history once again as President-elect Trump and Vice President-elect Pence swear to faithfully execute the duties of their elected offices and to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.  Read more in this week's column:

I extend my sincerest congratulations to President Trump and Vice President Pence. Today is a historic day for our nation, and it was a true honor to be outside the Capitol when our new president and vice president took their oaths of office. I’m thrilled to have the opportunity to work with the Trump administration to change the direction of our country, and I’m ready to get to work on behalf of Tennesseans.

ICYMI: I am extremely pleased that, as one of his first official actions, President Trump has directed our government to bring much-needed relief to the Americans struggling because of #Obamacare.   I share the president’s sense of urgency to right the wrongs of Obamacare, and I look forward to working with President Trump and Dr. Price to replace this failing law with patient-centered, market-based health care reform.
Yesterday was a great day. I am proud to support our president.
Proud to have supported this bill. I will always be #ProLife.   Look for more about how I'm standing up for life in tomorrow's column.

Now, more than ever, we need to take strategic and concrete steps to protect and secure our homeland, and I am glad President Trump has acted swiftly to fulfill his promise to build a wall. I’ve repeatedly said that a secure border is critical to restoring Americans’ confidence in their government.   Justifiably, East Tennesseans have been outraged over the last eight years as the previous administration picked and chose which laws to enforce, allowing so-called sanctuary cities around the country to refuse to abide by our country’s immigration laws while expecting federal funding. I am pleased the Trump administration is starting to restore the rule of law, and I thank President Trump for prioritizing this extremely important issue.

Today Senate VA Committee Chairman Johnny Isakson and I sent a letter to President Trump requesting guidance on how the federal hiring freeze will affect the VA.   One of our government's highest priorities - and VA's single most important mission - is to provide timely, high-quality care to the men and women who have bravely served our nation in uniform. It's important we ensure this hiring freeze won't have a negative impact on veteran care.   You can read more about the letter here:

Today is #MarchforLife. As an OBGYN, I delivered nearly 5,000 babies and spent my career in medicine caring for women. I wholeheartedly support women’s access to health care services, but abortions are not health care. As a health care provider, I have seen first-hand that life is a precious miracle, and have witnessed with my own eyes through the lens of an ultrasound that life begins at conception. I strongly support the sanctity of life, and will always speak up to defend the unborn. #ProLife  More on #WhyWeMarch in this week's column:

Do you need help with a federal agency but cannot make it to one of my district offices? My staff traveling office hours for the month of February are up on my website.  See when a staffer will be nearest you:

Judge Gorsuch is an excellent choice. He is a jurist in the mold of Justice Scalia and will fight to uphold our Constitution. I thank President Trump for keeping his promise to nominate a justice to the bench who is committed to the rule of law.

In 2015, federal regulations were estimated to cost roughly $1.89 trillion in lost growth and productivity. Further, if the United States’ regulatory system were a country, it would have the world’s 9th largest economy. Out-of-control regulating has undoubtedly slowed economic recovery, which is why I am proud that President Trump took major steps this week to ensure overregulation will no longer stand in the way of economic recovery.  President Trump is not alone in working to reduce the burden of regulations and pave the way for job creation; the House also passed two important measures to stop regulations put forward by the Obama administration.  Read more in this week's column:

Since 2010, I have chaired hearings, asked questions and written letters in an attempt to understand why the previous administration was pursuing this misguided rule. Our oversight exposed significant shortcomings with the rule, and I’m glad President Trump has signed an executive order to halt its implementation.   We can all agree financial advisors should serve their clients’ best interests, but the Fiduciary Rule was a solution in search of a problem and created an unnecessarily complicated bureaucracy that would have hurt low and middle class investors by driving up the cost of investment advice. I look forward to working with the Trump administration to ensure all Americans, no matter their background, can save for retirement.

Local control of education must be preserved. Just as a one-size-fits-all approach won’t work for health care reform, educators need the flexibility to do what’s best for their students.   Read more in this week's column:

I strongly disagree with this ruling. Other presidents have paused immigration from countries of concern in the past. How can any president protect our country if the courts won't allow them to do so?

I am thrilled my good friend, Dr. Tom Price, will serve as our next Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. Tom is an accomplished legislator with a strong grasp of what it will take to repeal and replace Obamacare, and I look forward to working with him to put patients back in charge of their health care decisions. I can't think of a better, more qualified person for this job and I commend President Trump and congratulate Dr. Price on this outstanding appointment.

I congratulate incoming Secretary Shulkin on his confirmation, and I look forward to meeting with him later this week to discuss VA reform. President Trump has made it clear that wholesale reform of VA is a top priority for his administration, and I’m confident we can work together to ensure our heroes have timely access to the services and benefits they’ve earned.   There is much work ahead, but the men and women who have served our country deserve better than the status quo. As chairman of the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs, I am committed to bringing accountability and reform to the department, and I know incoming Secretary Shulkin is as well.
It was an honor to be at the White House today for Secretary Shulkin's swearing-in. Congratulations, Mr. Secretary! Let's get to work on behalf of our heroes.
Great meeting with representatives from the Nashville Songwriters Association in DC this morning!

As a physician who practiced medicine in East Tennessee for more than thirty years, I got to know many of my constituents long before I ever ran for office. I know first-hand that East Tennesseans are some of the best people you’ll ever meet. East Tennesseans are first class citizens, and I wholeheartedly believe they deserve first class health care.  Tuesday evening I held a telephone town hall for constituents in the First District to discuss the issues facing them and their families. As many of you know, I regularly hold these calls as one means of hearing directly from East Tennesseans. We had a lot of questions related to the ACA, veterans’ benefits, and the new priorities of the Trump Administration. I also asked callers a simple poll question: do you support Congress acting to repeal and replace Obamacare? We had 650 constituents weigh in, and 538, or 83 percent, said Congress should act to repeal and replace Obamacare; 57, or 9 percent, said that Congress should leave Obamacare in place; and 55, or 8 percent, said they were unsure at this time. While the results aren’t scientific, the strength of support for repealing and replacing the ACA is telling.  Read more in this week's column:
I enjoyed speaking at the Salvation Army Souper Bowl for the Hungry event in Johnson City on Friday.   Photo credit: Earl Neikirk with the Bristol Herald Courier
If you missed my telephone town hall last week, you can listen to the full discussion here: https://vekeo.com/event/drphilroe-30768/.

President Trump put forward a bold, positive and encouraging agenda for our country tonight, and it was an honor to sit in the House chamber for his first joint address. I was proud to hear the president discuss our shared priorities like creating and keeping good-paying jobs; repealing and replacing Obamacare; ensuring we have a secure border and strong military; investing in infrastructure; and reforming the VA to work for our nation’s heroes.   This is the kind of vision and direction our country has lacked but desperately needed for the last eight years; and I look forward to working with President Trump and his administration to leave a better and stronger America for our children and grandchildren. #JointAddress

“Each American generation passes the torch of truth, liberty and justice in an unbroken chain all the way down to the present. That torch is now in our hands. And we will use it to light up the world. I am here tonight to deliver a message of unity and strength, and it is a message deeply delivered from my heart. A new chapter of American Greatness is now beginning. A new national pride is sweeping across our nation. And a new surge of optimism is placing impossible dreams firmly within our grasp.” –President Donald Trump  This week, President Trump gave his first joint address to Congress and to the American people. During this speech, President Trump laid out a bold, positive and encouraging agenda, and I personally thought it was one of the most powerful speeches we’ve heard from President Trump to date. For the last eight years, I’ve repeatedly said that our country needed strong leadership to put forward a clear vision and direction for the future, and the president’s address did just that. Our nation is still the best country in the world, but we’ve lost our way. We’ve got some work to do to leave a better, stronger America for our children and grandchildren, but President Trump was right to say we can’t do this alone. Republicans and Democrats must come together and finally put party politics aside to deliver the results the American people deserve.  Read more of my thoughts on President Trump's address in this week's column:

Earlier this week, I had the opportunity to meet with Michael J. Fox as part of the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research 2017 Parkinson's Policy Forum. I appreciated hearing from Mr. Fox about policies that can help Parkinson's patients and their caregivers.

Since I've served as your Congressman I've held more than 40 in-person town hall meetings. I'll be holding a town hall meeting in Greeneville next Monday at the Greene County Courthouse from 6:00 p.m. - 7:30 p.m.   As always, this event is free, open to the public and no tickets are required to attend. Parking will be available in the Courthouse parking lot after 5 p.m. Doors will open at 5:00 p.m. for seating, and seating will be first-come, first-served. Per court rules, please note that the use of cell phones is prohibited in the Courthouse.  You can find more information on my website. I look forward to seeing you Monday evening in Greeneville!
Happening Now: If you weren't able to make it to tonight's town hall meeting in Greeneville, you can watch it live here:

This bill isn’t just a promise kept, it’s good policy that will give every American who wants health coverage the ability to purchase it. We know Obamacare has failed, especially in East Tennessee where one-third of the counties in the First District will have no options for coverage under the Affordable Care Act come 2018. Unlike Obamacare, the American Health Care Act is being presented to the American people for their input and being debated in a transparent way. In fact, you can read the bill in full at readthebill.gop.  For the last seven years I’ve worked tirelessly to draft and put forward patient-centered health care reforms. I introduced a comprehensive package of reforms, and I’m pleased many of the provisions in my bill have been included in the American Health Care Act. I look forward to debating this legislation and enacting commonsense health care reform that will turn the page on Obamacare and give patients the coverage options they deserve. #RepealAndReplace #ReadTheBill
Too many first class people are getting second class health care. This week, we begin keeping the promise to repeal and replace Obamacare.   You can read the bill at readthebill.gop.
My weekly column is up on my website. I hope you'll take a moment to read about the work I'm doing at House Committee on Veterans' Affairs this week.
Next week the House will consider my bill to bring accountability to VA. Read about the bill at veterans.house.gov/accountability.

Despite the partisanship that accompanied passage of Obamacare, there are parts of this law that have earned bipartisan criticism, one being the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB). The IPAB is a board of 15 unelected, unaccountable bureaucrats created to reduce Medicare spending. The IPAB, once triggered, makes recommendations regarding cuts to Medicare without any Congressional oversight or input. IPAB proposals are considered using “fast track” procedures and, absent a three-fifths vote in the Senate, only allows Congress to modify the type of cuts to Medicare, not the amount.   If Congress fails to act on the board’s recommendations, they automatically go into effect. To make matters worse, the IPAB is exempt from any judicial or administrative review. Further, if the president doesn’t nominate anyone to serve on the IPAB, or if the IPAB fails to recommend Medicare spending reductions, the law gives the Secretary of Health and Human Services an enormous amount of power, allowing them to make changes to Medicare spending unilaterally. This means one person could have the power to drastically shape Medicare spending with no accountability to Congress, the administration or — most importantly — the American people.That's why I'm leading the charge to repeal the IPAB. You can read more in this guest post I wrote for the Neurosurgery blog.
Last Saturday, I had the pleasure of joining Tennessee Farm Bureau for their legislative breakfast in Jonesborough, TN. Thank you for having me!
Thank you @fightcrc for welcoming me to the Congressional Advisory Committee & fighting for a cure to colorectal cancer.

Last week, Speaker Ryan unveiled the American Health Care Act (AHCA), legislation that repeals Obamacare and lays the groundwork for a 21st century health care system. This legislation, which has been closely coordinated with the Trump administration, will increase access to affordable, flexible health care plans…   Instead of Tennesseans being forced to purchase a one-size-fits-all plan which empties their pockets and leaves low-and middle-income families behind, this plan will ensure all Americans have access to affordable, quality coverage. Learn more at readthebill.gop.  More info on this week’s column --> http://bit.ly/2mKARdH

Our veterans deserve better, and the VA employees who work tirelessly to fulfill their duties deserve better. Today, the House will vote on my bill to bring accountability to U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs.

The House just passed my legislation to ensure veterans Second Amendment rights are protected. I strongly believe we must do everything in our power to protect the rights guaranteed to all Americans, especially the men and women who have served, by the Constitution. The Veterans 2nd Amendment Protection Act does just that.  Read my full statement here --> http://bit.ly/2nf5T02

In case you missed it…  Speaker Paul Ryan supports our Desert Shield War Memorial Act. which will honor our veteran’s service with a memorial on the National Mall. Next stop to pass the bill --> The White House.   Note: All funds will be raised privately by the National Desert Storm War Memorial Association.   Read my full statement here: http://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398133

In case you missed it, I joined Fox Business Network today to talk about the health care bill to repeal and replace Obamacare coming up this Thursday.   “What we’re trying to do is expand coverage, lower cost, and put patients and doctors back in charge of health care decisions, which is what the Affordable Care Act didn’t do. It expanded coverage but it massively increased the cost and that’s the problem around the country now. People can’t afford their insurance.”  View here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wLuxMOTPhLc&feature=youtu.be

Thank you to all who attended the DAMA Subcommittee Roundtable today on appeals reform. I’d like to extend a special thank you to Rep. Mike Bost and Rep. Elizabeth Esty who helped lead an open and robust dialogue.

I am proud to reintroduce the AIM HIGH Act, which ensures students with disabilities have access to the same educational materials as other students. No student pursuing their education should be put at a disadvantage because they have a disability, and this bill simply encourages higher education institutions to provide equal access to all instructional materials. Read my statement here  --> http://bit.ly/2mQk24k

Today, President Trump signed S.J.Res. 1 into law, a resolution approving a location in Area I on the National Mall for the National Desert Storm and Desert Shield War Memorial. This law will enable the service members who fought in Operations Desert Storm and Desert Shield to have a memorial on the National Mall, like so many of their brothers and sisters in arms who served in prior conflicts.   Note: The United States currently lacks a national memorial dedicated to the service members who fought in Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm. All funds will be raised privately by the National Desert Storm War Memorial Association.   Read my full statement here: http://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398142
Join my Facebook Live Town Hall today at 4:30PM. What questions would you like to hear me answer?

Thank you to everyone who joined me during my Facebook Live town hall today! I enjoyed answering your questions and talking with constituents of the First District. We’ll let you know when we do it again.

Today I chaired a House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs hearing on the Veterans Crisis Line. We must ensure veterans in crisis have access to the resources they need. I’m also proud the committee launched a new website today. Visit veterans.house.gov for more on the hearing and to review the new site.

The House just passed legislation to eliminate the sunset date of the Choice program. By doing this, Congress is ensuring veterans have certainty and continuity of care while we work with the Trump administration to develop a strategic plan that addresses the need for a veteran-centric, coordinated network of care that utilizes the strengths of both VA and community health providers. Read my full statement here: go.usa.gov/xXnFf

I look forward to fixing our broken and outdated tax system to put taxpayers first.  Check out this week’s column here: http://bit.ly/2otaVG2

Happy Easter! I hope everyone is enjoying this Easter with loved ones and celebrating the resurrection of our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ.

Busy day in the district today: Toured Seimens & A.O. Smith Corporation this morning and a town hall in Elizabethton tonight. It begins at 6pm at TCAT Elizabethton. Looking forward to it!

This Saturday, April 29, 2017, marks President Trump’s 100th day in office as the President of the United States. Though there is much work ahead, I am pleased by the progress President Trump has made through Executive Actions and, most importantly, by teaming up with Congress. Together, we’ve put forward policies that put America first, proposals to bring accountability to government, and President Trump has used the power granted to Congress and the Office of the President in the Constitution to  roll back over burdensome regulations and enforce pro-growth policies.    Read my full column on how far we’ve come and what’s ahead --> http://bit.ly/2pjz80g

Great news! Today, President Trump signed an executive order creating the Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Office at the Department of Veterans Affairs. President Trump knows that holding VA employees to a higher standard and protecting the men and women who blow the whistle on injustices are essential to building a better VA.   See my full statement here:  http://bit.ly/2qc0YM6

Happy National Small Business Week! Did you know that 99% of all businesses with employees in the U.S. are small businesses? Veterans have the experience and skill set for becoming fantastic small business owners.

Thank you, American Conservative Union, for your commitment to America’s foundational principles and the Constitution. I’m honored to receive this award which represents my American Conservative Union Congressional rating of 96%.

Great news! H.R. 1180, the Working Families Flexibility Act of 2017, sponsored by my friend and colleague from Alabama, Representative Martha Roby just passed in the House. This commonsense piece of legislation would empower private-sector workers with the flexibility to choose comp time as compensation for working overtime hours, instead of added wages. Specifically, the provisions of this legislation would be completely voluntary for workers, allow them to exchange their accrued time for full overtime pay at any time or for any reason, and would maintain the protections of the Fair Labor Standards Act, such as the standard 40 hour work week.  https://youtu.be/WszgpNNUx9k

The American Dream is built on an individual’s ability to become entrepreneurs, take risks and build a small business that can thrive and grow. As we celebrate National Small Business Week, and as a former small business owner myself, I am aware of the many challenges these entrepreneurs face on a daily basis. That’s exactly why I make it a priority to visit small businesses across the First District of Tennessee to hear directly about their successes and challenges.   Read this week’s column here --> bit.ly/2qsuAaW

Today, I voted for the American Health Care Act. This bill has been years in the making, and I am proud to support it. As a doctor for over 30 years, I ran for Congress because I wanted to ensure Tennesseans have access to the quality health care they deserve.   This plan will dismantle Obamacare and replace it with patient-centered, free-market reforms. In stark contrast to Obamacare, the AHCA wasn’t developed by cutting backroom sweetheart deals with every special interest group that is invested in our health care system. We put patients first – they are our *ONLY* interest.  Read my full statement here:
Join us in congratulating Congressman Roe and Clarinda on their marriage this past weekend. -Team Roe
Happy National Teacher Appreciation Day! Thank you to the amazing, hardworking teachers of the First District of Tennessee who are shaping our future leaders! #iloveTNteachers

Last Thursday, Republicans in the House of Representatives took a giant step toward fulfilling our promise and President Trump’s pledge made to the American people that we would repeal Obamacare and replace it with patient-centered, free-market health care. The House-passed bill, H.R. 1628, the American Health Care Act (AHCA), will take away power from Washington bureaucrats and return it to the American people.   Despite a great deal of misinformation being circulated, the AHCA continues strong protections for people with pre-existing conditions. The AHCA requires insurers to cover individuals regardless of their health status, while also prohibiting insurers from charging higher premiums because of one’s illness.  Read this week’s column about the AHCA here: https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398163

I am proud to support our local, state & federal law enforcement today during National Police Week. We honor those who answer the call of duty in order to protect and defend the First District of Tennessee. Thank you for all you do to make our communities safe.

Today, in honor of National Police Week, I spoke on the House floor to support the Thin Blue Line Act -- legislation that honors and supports our law enforcement officers by making the killing or attempted killing of a law enforcement officer an aggravating factor for the imposition of the death penalty. They go to work every day to keep us safe and I am thankful for the sacrifices they make for the First District and our country.   https://t.co/p72HBnxxOW

East Tennesseans want and deserve a government that works. They deserve to know that they can trust their members of Congress to represent their views and interests each time they vote in Congress, and they deserve to know that real progress is being made on their behalf. Thank you for allowing me to represent you in the First District.    Read this week’s column on Congress’ accomplishments here:  http://bit.ly/2qH3HMi
OTD: June 1, 1796, Tennessee was the 16th state admitted to the Union. I'm thankful to call this state home. Happy Birthday Tennessee!

Thanks so much for participating in my Facebook Live town hall last week. I look forward to the next one! In addition to the questions I answered during the live discussion, I wanted to take a moment to address some of the other issues raised during the town hall.    With regard to health care, I've seen some questions about whether Congress exempted themselves from the American Health Care Act. Congressmen and women are not exempt. Because of the Senate rules on what can and cannot be included in a bill moved using reconciliation, the language that states Congress is not exempt could not be added to the American Health Care Act. That's why the House passed H.R. 2192, introduced by Martha McSally, by a vote of 429 to 0 before AHCA was considered. This measure will ensure members of Congress and their staffs are not exempt from this law.    I also noticed some questions about the number of town halls I've held this year. As you may know, I've held more than 40 in-person town hall meetings since I've served as your Congressman. Already this year, I've had in-person town hall meetings in Elizabethton and Greeneville, and have conducted other town halls via telephone and Facebook, and look forward to more in the future. Hearing from all constituents in the First District is an important part of the governing process, and I want to allow every East Tennessean the opportunity to let their voices be heard.    Finally, we had a number of questions from veterans about new opioid regulations at the VA. Opioid abuse is a national concern - and is prevalent in both the general and veterans populations - but some of the VA’s own practices have exacerbated this problem, such as an initial unwillingness to work with state prescribing databases. While there is no question the VA needed to take steps to curb opioid prescriptions for veterans whose pain may be able to be treated effectively without their use, taking away veterans' access to prescription medication without other options to manage their pain and close clinical supervision isn’t the answer either. That's why, as chairman of the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs, I am working to examine our policies on pain management and to ensure additional treatment options are available to treat chronic pain. The No Hero Left Untreated Act was passed by the House just last week. This bill would create a pilot program to allow the use of Magnetic Resonant Therapy, an innovative, FDA-approved treatment for patients with mental health conditions and chronic pain. I will continue to conduct oversight on this issue to ensure veterans are receiving the care they need from VA and that VHA clinics and hospitals are doing their fair share to combat to the opioid epidemic.    I encourage you to check my website regularly for information on town halls and to email or call any of my offices if I can assist you or your family. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

I am a co-sponsor of H.R. 930, the Lymphedema Treatment Act, which allows certain lymphedema compression treatment items to be covered as durable medical equipment under Medicare. Today marks American Eagle Day, a day to celebrate the recovery and restoration of the bald eagle, the national symbol of the United States. In 1782 on this day, the bald eagle was placed at the center of the Great Seal of the United States. It has served to symbolize the pride of America’s skies and the living symbol of all that America stands for.   I thank the American Eagle Foundation for founding this day to celebrate the bald eagles recovery from extinction. Learn more at americaneagleday.org.

America is a nation of laws and unfortunately, for the past 8 years, our immigration laws were inconsistently enforced, which makes these preventable crimes all the more tragic. East Tennessee experienced its own tragedy just last April when Ms. Shirra Branum, a 37-year-old mother, was killed in a motor vehicle accident with a car driven by an illegal immigrant who was allegedly driving intoxicated.   I am proud to support Kate’s Law, a bill to enhance penalties on deported felons who have returned to the United States. I also strongly believe that cities across the country that fail to comply with federal immigration laws should lose their federal funding, which is why I also support the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act.   Read my full statement on these two important bills that passed through the House of Representatives today: bit.ly/2s7faX2

Yesterday, President Trump signed my bill to extend and expand GI Bill benefits into law. This law removes time restrictions to use the GI Bill, enabling future eligible recipients to use their GI bill benefits for their entire lives, as opposed to the current 15-year timeline. It provides significant increases in GI Bill funding for Reservists and Guardsmen, dependents, surviving spouses and surviving dependents. It also provides 100% GI Bill eligibility to Post 9/11 Purple Heart recipients. You can read more about the bill at veterans.house.gov.   I thank President Trump for his support of this important, bipartisan package. #ForeverGIBill

I’m proud to say that my bipartisan bill, H.R. 849, the Protecting Seniors’ Access to Medicare Act of 2017 is being considered by the House tomorrow. This bill would repeal one of the worst parts of Obamacare, the Independent Payment Advisory Board, or IPAB. The IPAB is a unelected, unaccountable board of bureaucrats with sweeping powers to reduce Medicare spending. No matter your views on Obamacare, we should all be able to agree that giving an unelected panel this much power is a bad idea.  Read more about in this week’s column: https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398245
Today, I spoke on the House floor in support of my bipartisan bill to repeal one of the worst parts of Obamacare, the IPAB. WATCH:

Extremely proud of H.R. 849 which passed with a 307 to 111 strong bipartisan vote in the House today to repeal #IPAB.   Read more about the Protecting Seniors’ Access to Medicare Act of 2017 here: https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398246

Tax reform will help Tennessee families by allowing you to keep more of your hard-earned pay and bringing good-paying jobs to our state.   Read the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act at https://fairandsimple.gop.

Today, I spoke on the House floor in support of #HR3441, legislation to provide clarity and stability to job creators. Unelected NLRB bureaucrats and regulators have tried to drastically change what constitutes a “joint employer,” creating uncertainty for America’s employers and entrepreneurs, particularly those who utilize the franchise model to build their businesses. H.R. 3441 reaffirms that two or more employers must have “actual, direct, and immediate” control over employees to be considered joint employers under the National Labor Relations Act and Fair Labor Standards Act. This standard has worked for more than 30 years and helps support local businesses.

The Tax Cuts & Jobs Act passed the House today which is another huge step in delivering real and meaningful tax relief to East Tennessee families. Tax reform is a once-in-a-generation opportunity that will help individuals, families and businesses in East Tennessee thrive under a simplified tax code that lowers the tax burden for low- and middle-income families, allows you to keep more of the money you earn and allows businesses to be more competitive. I thank President Trump for supporting commonsense, pro-growth tax reform and making it a priority for his administration.  https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398254

ICYMI: Yesterday the House passed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, a huge win for the First District.   Read more: http://www.johnsoncitypress.com/Government/2017/11/16/Q-A-with-Roe-on-tax-overhaul.html?ci=stream&lp=9&p=1

Today is National Adoption Day, a day to raise awareness of the almost 110,000 foster children in need of a family and to celebrate the families across the nation who welcome children into their homes. I’m glad the tax reform legislation that passed the House on Thursday preserves the adoption tax credit for the families who open their homes and hearts to these special children. Read more about National Adoption day here: http://www.nationaladoptionday.org.

Wishing you and your family a very happy Thanksgiving! As Americans, we have so much to be grateful for. This Thanksgiving, I am thankful for the many blessings from our Creator, my loving family and the opportunity to represent you in Congress.

Yesterday marked the one year anniversary of the Sevier County wildfires. I am grateful for the fire fighters and first responders who worked through the night to evacuate residents to safety, and my thoughts and prayers continue to be with Sevier Countians as they rebuild. I remain available to assist the families affected by this tragedy in any way that I can. #SmokiesStrong.   http://www.knoxnews.com/topic/113a1b22-75d9-4b94-ba3a-9164cbf526b9/gatlinburg-fire-anniversary/

This week, Congress returned to Washington with a full to-do list after Thanksgiving. While there is a lot on our plate, I’m confident we can work together to get the results the American people deserve. I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues in Congress and the Trump administration to make this country the best that it can be.   Read more on what is on Congress’ agenda this month:  https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398256
It was great to spend time with my family over Thanksgiving. Here are the Roe granddaughters oldest to youngest. I’m thankful to be their Pop! #tbt

Today we are one step closer to overhauling our tax code and seizing a once-in-a-generation opportunity to allow hardworking Americans to keep more of their pay. I am optimistic Congress can get this bill to the president’s desk before Christmas. https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398258

A major overhaul of our tax code is coming & I am proud of the progress we’ve made to help middle-class Americans keep more of the money they earn & provide for their families. Need a quick refresher on what Congress has done thus far?
I am proud to stand with my colleagues to defend the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding Americans. Read more: https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398260
Today is Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day. Join me in remembering the lives lost and honoring the patriots, both past and present, who defend our great nation.   “A date which will live in infamy.”

Last week I had the privilege of participating in the ribbon cutting of Carter County’s Early Head Start programs provided by the Telamon Corporation. I’m proud of the work they do to provide quality services for families in the First District.

I am proud to be an original cosponsor of the RETIRE Act which would automatically enroll participants in electronic delivery for retirement plan communications. Learn more here: https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398261
Today, the House Committee on Education and the Workforce is marking up the Promoting Real Opportunity, Success, and Prosperity through Education Reform (PROSPER) Act.    Watch my statement here:

Helping students gain access to higher education is one of the most important jobs I have in Congress. I am proud of the #PROSPER Act and want to thank Rep. Virginia Foxx for her leadership on this legislation. https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398262
On the 226th anniversary of the Bill of Rights, we recognize and celebrate the individual freedoms guaranteed to us through the first ten amendments to the Constitution.

Busy weekend this past weekend. I spoke to a US government class at Seymour High School, gave Morristown Kiwanis Club a Washington update and concluded by speaking at ETSU’s graduation. What an honor!

Great news! The House just passed the conference report for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. This bill is a win for East Tennesseans, and the proof will be in Tennesseans’ paychecks. Looking forward to seeing President Donald J. Trump sign this bill into law.  https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398264

We’re fortunate to wake up every day in the greatest country in the world, and we owe it all to the men and women who serve in our nation’s armed forces. Let's remember to pray for our servicemembers who are overseas during this Christmas season.  https://roe.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398265
